fields.summary: [C++] Add option to convert a particular column to timestamps or dates using a passed strptime-compatible string

bkietz commented on pull request #6631: ARROW-8111: [C++][CSV] Support MM/DD/YYYY date format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6631#discussion_r393033266
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/util/parsing.h
 ##########
 @@ -374,13 +374,25 @@ class StringConverter<TimestampType> {
     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mmZ"
     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mm:ss"
     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mm:ssZ"
+    // - "MM/DD/YYYY"
 
 Review comment:
   As [discussed in the JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-8111?focusedCommentId=17058819&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-17058819), this format is too locale specific for an unconditional inference like this (as it only makes sense for dates originating in the US). Please remove it

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6631#discussion_r393057663

     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mm:ssZ"
+    // - "MM/DD/YYYY"
 
 Review comment:
   My gut feeling is that we should center efforts on the API user supplying strptime-like format strings like "%m/%d/%Y". For now you can special case the one you have implemented until a more general parser can be implemented.
   
   At some point we might also need to add a functional API where the user passes an opaque parsing function.

wesm commented on pull request #6631: ARROW-8111: [C++][CSV] Support MM/DD/YYYY date format
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6631#discussion_r393064826

     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mm:ss"
     // - "YYYY-MM-DD[ T]hh:mm:ssZ"
+    // - "MM/DD/YYYY"
 
 Review comment:
   `StringConverter<TimestampType>` is used here
   
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/csv/converter.cc#L393
   
   So two options:
   
   * Introduce an alternative code path for user-supplied format (versus using the ISO-8601 converter) -- this is probably what I would do
   * Add options to `StringConverter<TimestampType>`. @pitrou may have a preference since he has worked on this code
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Currently, date parser supports only YYYY-MM-DD format. For our workload we need MM/DD/YYYY format. It is obvious that CSV parser should support different date formats, so we may start from implementing MM/DD/YYYY format. 

Also, we may use some date parsing library, which would solve the problem for us.

Also, we may need to somehow specify a format for every column in CSV parser. 

If you have any implementation ideas in mind, please share, so that I can implement it.

comments.body:
That sounds like a good idea (though it might confuse our US users :-)).
The parsing code is in {{arrow/util/parsing.h}}.

[~apitrou], yeah, I saw it, and I was able to patch it to support DD/MM/YYYY, but I'm not sure that adding just this format would be good enough to merge it in upstream. If it is ok, then I could just publish my patch, if its not, then we need to think about the more general solution of supporting more standard formats, or even custom time format.
I think it would be good start. Supporting more formats unambiguously is probably a bit delicate.
And if you do, ensure to write the equialent JSON parser test so we benefit from both!

This is related to ARROW-3739 which would provide support for strptime-compatible format strings. It doesn't sound sustainable for you to be maintaining patched versions of the code so it would be good to have a solution in the main project
Note we could recognize certain common strptime patterns (e.g. {{"%m/%d/%Y"}}) and use a more optimized / specialized code path for parsing.
I'm not sure we should gold-plate it :-) For now recognizing an additional, widespread hard-coded format sounds good.

Right, but in terms of creating a public API to expose this functionality, I think it would be better to be explicit about what format is expected rather than unconditionally making an inference (in this particular case, the inference could be wrong if the data is of US origin -- since we use MM/DD/YYYY). If the user indicates a format that is not supported yet we can say so
Ok, thanks, folks! I'll create a draft patch soon to discuss more in detail.

Oh, I found that we actually needed US MM/DD/YYYY format, so I will rename the issue :) 
Also, for disambiguate US and EU formats we can add explicit locale param to the parser.
